executive_summary: The Millwork Product Wholesaling industry distributes a range of wood windows, doors, flooring and other wood and metal millwork products. The industry is heavily dependent on domestic construction activity and generates the majority of revenue from residential construction in particular. Over the five years to 2021, the industry has benefited from strong growth in housing starts and private spending on home improvements. Even during the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic, operators performed reasonably well, given the boost the crisis has had on housing markets.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Revenue growth fueled by housing starts
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The Millwork Product Wholesaling industry has experienced strong revenue growth over the five years to 2021. This growth has been fueled by increases in housing starts and residential construction overall. Because the majority of the industry's revenue is derived from residential housing markets, strong performance in this market segment is crucial to boosting demand for industry products.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Pandemic impact and supply chain disruptions
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Industry growth has been further boosted by the coronavirus pandemic as consumers have increased their spending on home improvements. Although some operators in this industry also manufacture metal versions of industry products, the majority of industry revenue is generated by wood products. As a result, the price of sawmill lumber heavily influences this industry. As the price of sawmill lumber has increased during the current period, profit has contracted. In addition, the pandemic in 2020 and 2021 has caused some domestic supply chain disruptions, as many millwork manufacturers were forced to cease operations temporarily.

The fall in profit has caused declines in the number of industry operators, which has been further exaggerated by increased merger and acquisition activity as larger companies take advantage of economies of scale to increase their profit.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Over the five years to 2026, industry revenue growth is expected to slow in line with subdued growth in residential construction levels. Housing starts and private spending on home improvements are also expected to slow compared to the previous period, further tempering growth in industry revenue.
Conversely, nonresidential construction is expected to grow more quickly than during the previous period, which will boost demand from business markets.

Overall, industry revenue is expected to grow at an annualized rate of 1.2% to $34.9 billion over the five years to 2026. Profit is expected to stagnate in line with slow growth in revenue, causing further declines in the number of industry operators.

industry_definition: This industry distributes a range of wood windows, doors, flooring and other millwork products, in addition to metal versions of these products. Companies also wholesale a range of hardwood and softwood cut stock and dimension stock timber (lumber and worked wood products cut or shaped into specialized sizes). These products are primarily sold to contractors and home improvement stores.

negative_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: low - steady

key_trends: Strong residential construction and improvement have driven demand for lumber
Climbing lumber prices have contributed to contractions in profit margins
Consolidation has occurred due to acquisition activity by the industry's larger operators
The Millwork Product Wholesaling industry is in the mature phase of its life cycle.
The number of industry operators is expected to grow slowly
Industry products are well-established and have widespread market acceptance

market_segmentation.segment_description: New residential construction is the largest market for the Millwork Products Wholesaling industry, accounting for an estimated 44.1% of revenue in 2021. Operators in the industry primarily serve this market through a wide distribution network of distributors to reach the desired end market.

The residential repair and remodeling market is the second-largest market for industry operators and anticipated to account for 35.8% of industry revenue in 2021. Industry operators are likely to distribute products through large retailers and other intermediary wholesalers within this segment.

Nonresidential construction is anticipated to account for 20.1% of industry revenue in 2021. Activity within this market is mainly commercial construction. Consequently, sales for industry products within this segment are distributed through local, regional and national contractors in addition to intermediary distributors.

products_and_services.product_description: The distribution of windows and doors represent a majority of revenue in the Millwork Products Wholesaling industry. Interior and exterior doors and windows are used primarily in the new residential, commercial and nonresidential markets.

Wholesaling flooring is anticipated to account for 29.0% of industry revenue in 2021. The majority of the millwork used in floors is wood, but also includes a marginal amount of metal millwork. Floors are primarily made from hardwoods and softwoods.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Wholesaling Cut Stock and Dimension Lumber
products_and_services.product_description: Dimension lumber is either from softwood or hardwood, and cut to a predetermined width and depth, specified in inches. Dimensional lumber is used to measure the proper dimensions in framing wood-based buildings, and limited by the height and girth of the tree it was milled from.

tier_2_suppliers: Sawmills & Wood Production in the US
tier_1_buyers: Manufactured Home Dealers in the US
tier_2_buyers: Small Specialty Retail Stores in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Downstream construction markets encompass residential construction, residential repair and remodeling and nonresidential construction. These markets are highly cyclical and often tied to the overall strength of the economy. Consequently, demand follows trends such as national occupancy rates, access to credit, spending on home improvement and housing starts among others.

Trends in the supply chain also directly affect demand for millwork product wholesalers. For example, as demand for industry products increases, it limits the number of suppliers with adequate capacity to meet the increased global demand. Consequently, this increases pricing for industry products, which can affect preferences and short-term contracts of downstream purchasers. Furthermore, unanticipated tariffs or trade restrictions can have an adverse effect on upstream manufacturers and pose difficulties in production or delivery. Additionally, some industry products are subject to regulation, and changes in policy can delay the delivery of raw materials, hindering the overall supply chain.
Consequently, any interruption in the distribution network of industry operators could affect their ability to fulfill orders in time and could affect demand for industry operators.

Demand for industry products are also at the whim of downstream preferences, which can shift without notice. Substitute products that are eco-friendly could pose a threat to industry demand. Additionally, substitutes that are have a longer life and are more durable than millwork products could adversely affect revenue for industry operators.

international_trade_points.trade_description: The Millwork Product Wholesaling industry does not have international trade, as all trade for millwork products is recorded at the manufacturing level. Wholesaling industries, by definition, only include domestic commerce.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast region includes two of the largest five states in the production of millwork products, Florida and North Carolina, accounting for 7.4% and 5.0% of industry establishments, respectively. This is partly due to the access to a local distribution network and upstream industry establishments, as the Southeast is the nation's largest producer of lumber.

The West region accounts for 17.8% of the residential population, and captures 18.4% of establishments within the Millwork Products and Wholesaling industry. Almost half of the share is accounted for by California, which represents 9.6% of industry establishments. This is primarily due to California's proximity to dense forests, which are vital to industry products. Additionally, California alone accounts for 12.1% of the residential population, which indicates a wide dispersal for industry products across the state. A strong housing demand coupled with a large consumer market makes the West particularly attractive for industry establishments.

regulations_points.regulation_description: There are not a lot of regulatory problems that are specific to the Millwork Product Wholesaling industry. Instead, industry operators experience general regulations that cover the storage and transportation of goods.
Industry operators are required to comply with environmental laws, which cover noise pollution, solid waste emissions and treatment.
Some states and districts also impose separate regulations, which are binding within their regional jurisdiction.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The industry has a low level of capital intensity, meaning the requirements for machinery or technological systems are easily attainable with access to capital.
New entrants may experience difficulty obtaining customers from legacy operators, as relationships with retailers and distributors are often complex.

basis_points.basis_description: Competition is based on the functional and aesthetic quality of products.
Price is one of the most important factors, as consumers can easily compare prices.
Competition is rooted in distribution networks, where reliability, speed and service quality are integral.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The industry is highly fragmented, composed mostly of small and medium-sized operators.
In 2021, the top two companies are expected to generate less than 5% of industry revenue.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Industry profit, defined as earnings before interest and taxes, is expected to account for 3.3% of industry revenue in 2021. This is a decline from 3.7% of industry revenue in 2016.
Wage costs have increased somewhat during the period, as industry revenue growth has driven industry operators to expand their labor forces.
Purchases are the largest cost segment for industry operators, which is typical for a wholesaling industry. Purchase costs are heavily influenced by the price of sawmill lumber.
Depreciation costs are typically relatively negligible for this industry, as wholesaling industries tend to not accrue significant depreciation expenses.
Marketing expenses are low for this industry, as industry operators typically rely on pre-existing relationships with businesses and other prospective buyers to generate revenue.
Operators primarily occur rental expenses by paying rent on facilities used to store industry merchandise.
Utilities costs are typically relatively low for this industry.
Other costs, including legal, administrative and insurance costs, are expected to account for 12.5% of industry revenue in 2021.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The Millwork Product Wholesaling industry has a low level of capital intensity, which is typical for a wholesaling industry.

volatility_points.volatility_description: The Millwork Product Wholesaling industry has experienced a moderate level of revenue volatility over the five years to 2021.
This industry tends to have a moderate level of volatility, as demand for industry products typically ebbs and flows in line with the residential housing market.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The Millwork Product Wholesaling industry has experienced a low level of technological change over the five years to 2021.
Industry operators are dependent on high level information technology systems, which enable business functions.

FAQs.question: What are the key data points related to the softwood lumber industry?
FAQs.answer: The key data points provided include industry turnover, industry gross product, number of establishments, number of enterprises, employment, exports, imports, total wages, and domestic demand for various years from 2003 to 2013.

FAQs.question: What is the range of duties imposed by the US government on softwood lumber imported from Canada?
FAQs.answer: The duty on all softwood lumber imported from Canada ranges from 10.0% to almost 24.0% depending on the manufacturer.

FAQs.question: How do the tariffs impact industry operators?
FAQs.answer: The tariffs make procurement of inputs more expensive since the upstream market is less competitive. Industry operators cannot always pass price increases onto buying markets and may need to cut into profit instead.
